item.description:
@AlexandraErin @tompeyer There used to be such people. They fought government suppression of speech at the Supreme Court and, in the 60s and 70s, decisively won. I expect we’ll see such people again soon at the Supreme Court, decisively losing in the 20s and 30s.

@AlexandraErin @tompeyer Ms. Paul is making their work harder.
item.source:markdown:
@AlexandraErin @tompeyer There used to be such people. They fought government suppression of speech at the Supreme Court and, in the 60s and 70s, decisively won. I expect we’ll see such people again soon at the Supreme Court, decisively losing in the 20s and 30s.
@AlexandraErin @tompeyer Ms. Paul is making their work harder.

item.description: @matthewjmiller7 @DBashIdeas Let me know if you want a review copy for the New Books Network.
item.source:markdown: @matthewjmiller7 @DBashIdeas Let me know if you want a review copy for the New Books Network.

item.description:
Your reminder that the NYTimes pays people to produce right wing disinformation, which generally works by highlighting a minor situation to obscure a major situation. https://t.co/hfjKycGNm2

Note that this works only because the NYTimes downplays right wing bad behavior. If Republican efforts in Virginia to sue book publishers and reverse decades of First Amendment law had been properly reported by the “paper of record,” the columnist couldn’t have ignored it.

And yes, there is a book that @BenYehudaPress hopes to publish in the next year or two which may be illegal to sell in certain states by then, given the Republican Supreme Court’s pledged goal of returning the Constitution to its 18th or 19th century reading.

I’m willing to gamble the minuscule advance I pay my authors that the #RogueSCOTUS will be right-sized before it rules on these matters and obligates Amazon to restrict sales of the book in Red States.

But if I were paying real money — you better believe there’d be a chilling effect.

But Ms. Paul’s job is not going explicitly not to tell you that Lolita and Origin of the Species could plausibly be banned in American states before the decade is over.
item.source:markdown:
Your reminder that the NYTimes pays people to produce right wing disinformation, which generally works by highlighting a minor situation to obscure a major situation. https://t.co/hfjKycGNm2
Note that this works only because the NYTimes downplays right wing bad behavior. If Republican efforts in Virginia to sue book publishers and reverse decades of First Amendment law had been properly reported by the “paper of record,” the columnist couldn’t have ignored it.
And yes, there is a book that @BenYehudaPress hopes to publish in the next year or two which may be illegal to sell in certain states by then, given the Republican Supreme Court’s pledged goal of returning the Constitution to its 18th or 19th century reading.
I’m willing to gamble the minuscule advance I pay my authors that the #RogueSCOTUS will be right-sized before it rules on these matters and obligates Amazon to restrict sales of the book in Red States.
But if I were paying real money — you better believe there’d be a chilling effect.
But Ms. Paul’s job is not going explicitly not to tell you that Lolita and Origin of the Species could plausibly be banned in American states before the decade is over.

item.description:
@JeffSharlet I wish there were some discussion of an off-ramp. A formal way for people to say, “I used to be a Republican, but I’m no longer aboard. I did not sign up sedition and banning birth control and putting gays back in the closet. For the conceivable future, I’m outta there”

@JeffSharlet Something I could give my kids to make the case to their grandfather. Who is really a much nicer person than the fascist politics he has drifted into quietly acceding to.
item.source:markdown:
@JeffSharlet I wish there were some discussion of an off-ramp. A formal way for people to say, “I used to be a Republican, but I’m no longer aboard. I did not sign up sedition and banning birth control and putting gays back in the closet. For the conceivable future, I’m outta there”
@JeffSharlet Something I could give my kids to make the case to their grandfather. Who is really a much nicer person than the fascist politics he has drifted into quietly acceding to.

item.description: @bogiperson I’m so American, since the topic wasn’t explicitly weather I read it as Farenheit, admired their fortitude in braving the cold, and ignored the thought that “hey, since when is Hungary in the Southern Hemisphere?”
item.source:markdown: @bogiperson I’m so American, since the topic wasn’t explicitly weather I read it as Farenheit, admired their fortitude in braving the cold, and ignored the thought that “hey, since when is Hungary in the Southern Hemisphere?”

item.description:
One of the wonderful things of being of a certain age is that I have wonderful nostalgic childhood memories of typewriters which renew my deep appreciation for having moved past that technology. https://t.co/4bI8foGDOP

Likewise with programming with punch cards, only more so. Much more so, because the Fun Thing about punchcards is that there was no backspace key or Witeout. Make a mistake and you have to retype the card (a line of code) from scratch.
item.source:markdown:
One of the wonderful things of being of a certain age is that I have wonderful nostalgic childhood memories of typewriters which renew my deep appreciation for having moved past that technology. https://t.co/4bI8foGDOP
Likewise with programming with punch cards, only more so. Much more so, because the Fun Thing about punchcards is that there was no backspace key or Witeout. Make a mistake and you have to retype the card (a line of code) from scratch.

item.description:
I read the chapters on Pinchas and Mattot-Massei this Shabbos. https://t.co/wJaCba7ajG

For Pinchas, Rabbi Feigelson looks at the Avodat Yisrael by the Maggid of Kozhnitz; for M-M the Izhbitzer.

Coming in time for Simchat Torah from @BenYehudaPress https://t.co/tbpaTPbgnT

Rabbi Feigelson leads @theIJSS_ and this work uses Chassidic teachings — included in the original along with a translation — to discuss contemporary issues.

For Pinchas, he starts by looking to R Jonathan Sacks to frame the distinction between unity and wholeness.
item.source:markdown:
I read the chapters on Pinchas and Mattot-Massei this Shabbos. https://t.co/wJaCba7ajG
For Pinchas, Rabbi Feigelson looks at the Avodat Yisrael by the Maggid of Kozhnitz; for M-M the Izhbitzer.
Coming in time for Simchat Torah from @BenYehudaPress https://t.co/tbpaTPbgnT
Rabbi Feigelson leads @theIJSS_ and this work uses Chassidic teachings — included in the original along with a translation — to discuss contemporary issues.
For Pinchas, he starts by looking to R Jonathan Sacks to frame the distinction between unity and wholeness.

item.description:
@trekonomics One possible tell of cryotofascist religious apologetics/propaganda is the cargo cult usage of terms such as “progress” and “Christianity” without actually engaging with the facts and ideas they’re ostensibly pointing to.

@trekonomics Is he calling for a return of sumptuary laws? A ban on interest bearing loans? Disenfranchising Jews? just to take three historical examples of an actual Christian legal order.
item.source:markdown:
@trekonomics One possible tell of cryotofascist religious apologetics/propaganda is the cargo cult usage of terms such as “progress” and “Christianity” without actually engaging with the facts and ideas they’re ostensibly pointing to.
@trekonomics Is he calling for a return of sumptuary laws? A ban on interest bearing loans? Disenfranchising Jews? just to take three historical examples of an actual Christian legal order.

item.description: @moorehn @Chronotope Another way to understand it is that the current editor of the Atlantic used to be a lead reporter for The Forward when it was run by WSJ vet Seth Lipsky, who let culture warrior neoconservatives act as assignment editors.
item.source:markdown: @moorehn @Chronotope Another way to understand it is that the current editor of the Atlantic used to be a lead reporter for The Forward when it was run by WSJ vet Seth Lipsky, who let culture warrior neoconservatives act as assignment editors.
